title: Chandemau
text:
Chandemau is a village in <a href="Khiron">Khiron</a> block of <a href="Rae%20Bareli%20district">Rae Bareli district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located 18 km from <a href="Lalganj%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Lalganj</a>, the tehsil headquarters. As of 2011, it has a population of 1,135 people, in 230 households. It has 1 primary school and no healthcare facilities and it does not host a weekly <a href="haat">haat</a> or a permanent market. It belongs to the <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> of <a href="Bhitargaon">Bhitargaon</a>.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Chandemau (as "Chande Mau") as comprising 5 hamlets, with a total population of 327 people (181 male and 146 female), in 58 households and 68 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 444 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. 4 residents were literate, all male. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of Khiron and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of <a href="Gurbakshganj">Gurbakshganj</a>.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Chandemau as comprising 5 hamlets, with a total population of 385 people (214 male and 171 female), in 76 households and 66 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 444 <a href="acre">acre</a>s.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Chandemau (as "Chandeymau") as having a population of 640 people, in 132 households, and having an area of 173.60 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were given as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Chandemau (as "Chande Mau") as having a total population of 749 people (371 male and 378 female), in 134 households and 134 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 172 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 179, or 24% of the total; this group was 58% male (104) and 42% female (75). Members of <a href="scheduled%20castes">scheduled castes</a> made up 31% of the village's population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 17% (91 men and 39 women). 324 people were classified as main workers (158 men and 166 women), while 0 people were classified as marginal workers; the remaining 425 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 260 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 63 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 0 workers in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 0 household industry workers; 0 workers employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 0 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 1 employed in trade and commerce; 0 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 0 in other services.
